comments.commentBody:
TWTDs has always been a favorite. I don't think I knew the Mary Hopkin (in any language); I'm not sure whose cover I most associate it with, but found this version that has a nice feel of the gypsy to it. That might be on account of the horses, however.

I'd be interested to hear if/how it strikes y'all, too.

But the shareholders of these companies would not allow their investments to take the principled high road by not taking advantage of the currently corrupt political process. The only sane recourse is public financing of elections.

Not allowing companies to give $100K checks for private dinners with Governors is how you reform this government, not a smaller government (and I'm not even sure what smaller gov't means, no schools, highway repair...what?)

Just so I understand, Donna, are you saying every American is entitled to a free car? I am trying to figure out another way your post can be interpreted. And if so who should pay for it? And what class of car? A Benz, a Honda, a Ford?
Cable TV and cars are both luxuries.  They are not necessities for life.

According to the article:
http://www.citylab.com/commute/2014/07/how-low-income-commuters-view-cyc...
From the article:
"Most people, poor and non-poor alike, still want cars. In 2012, survey participants ranked car ownership as the most desirable among nine transportation mode options. In 2013, 55 percent of respondents strongly agreed with the statement "I want to own my own car." Even increasingly popular car-sharing was not satisfying for respondents; when asked if they would "rather share a car through a program like Zipcar or Car2Go than own my own vehicle," 35 percent strongly disagreed. Also, 32 percent strongly disagreed with "I want a lifestyle where I don't need to own a car."
Our study showed that African Americans were statistically more likely than other demographic groups to desire to own a car. But they were also less likely to include biking in their ideal mode of transit. Notably, our respondents were concerned about transportation costs and cognizant of car-related expenses. While recognizing many downsides of car ownership, our respondents said they wanted cars nonetheless. For low-income people...
"Automobility remains a paradoxical cultural and status symbol, poor people still aspire to car ownership." In 2012, respondents ranked cycling seventh out of nine transport modes, ahead of only taxis and bike sharing. In 2013, respondents reported more than 30 barriers to cycling or walking. One respondent said, simply, "I just want a car."

Without conditions that make repossession easy, no one would have made auto loans to these high risk creditors, or lenders would have insisted on exorbitant interest rates.

For whatever reason, these borrowers have a history of failing to honor their financial obligations - that's why their credit rating is poor. The fact that they even have a vehicle, which some here have labeled an "absolute necessity", is due to the existence of this type of high risk loan. These type of loans would dry up if lenders could not quickly recoup some of their loss via quick repossession and sale.

These loans were an opportunity for those who had ruined their credit to start back on the road to financial recovery. They blew it.

Zero sympathy for the vast majority of these borrowers.

Only those who had been living well within their means and then encountered totally unexpected financial difficulties, deserve any sympathy. And it is not for the auto lenders to be the source of help for these.
Yeah, maybe we can do a kickstarter campaign for buying influence.

Robert F. - does a person really have to be a "right wing extremist" to "suggest that history teaching materials should "promote citizenship, patriotism ... (and) respect for authority" and not "encourage or condone civil disorder, social strife or disregard of the law."?

Would a nice progressive then want history teaching materials that DID encourage or condone civil disorder or disregard of the law? Really? And are you also then saying that promoting citizenship is a right-wing extremist only educational goal?
You mean women who become doctors and lawyers didn't choose their careers?
I am not sure about that.  Once the door was open for women to become doctors and lawyers, the numbers grew very quickly.

I disagree with the idea that labels are a substitute for understanding. The key bit of societal understanding that we need is that all expressions of sexuality (which includes asexuality) are equally valid and deserving of respect and equitable treatment under the law. For society to reach this point, labels are in fact essential. Without labels, one is trying to sweep the differences under the rug, not celebrating them. After all, no one is proposing that we stop noticing that the other person is a woman or a man, or outlawing these two words.

Vive la difference!

not really Nancy - I work for a tech company and have been threatened by a low performing female that ungarded comments are being noted and will be reported to HR, despite them being contextual to the work I'm doing that expores both modern feminity & masculinity; case in point a quote about Uncle Terry that I distrubuted was deemed offensive until it got to HR, who ismissed the complaint.  This is the 3rd time in the last 20 years that this has happened - all because women wanted to be accepted then played the sexism card to manipulate the position.

That's an interesting anecdote, but in my 20 years in tech the after work activity has never been a strip club.  Most engineers in Silicon Valley have families.  Younger engineers tend to do outdoor activities or socialize in San Francisco.

The latest proof that ESPN is just the worst bunch of corporate phonies...Takes a stand on nothing until it becomes consensus opinion, transparent shill for any league/player important to their ratings, only willing to ever criticize marginal figures

Simmons got it for the obcenities. At least that is what ESPN would claim. The real problem for the NFL and what Simmons needs to keep writing about even if he is gone from ESPN are the injuries in the modern pro game. I simply do not understand how the level of carnage is acceptable.

Every week, major players are knocked out for the season. Some have their playing careers ended. They fade into obscurity and the league has done little to help them get on with life.

The whole NFL thing has become grotesque. Godell is the face of the grotesqueness. Perhaps that is why Simmons lost it and went full rant. I say, 'good on him.'

I also say, 'hope you saved your cash, because you have a target on your back at ESPN now.'

Scientists have been grappling with the lack of warming in the atmosphere (technically it's the mean surface temperature that has not been increasing) and recently they've come to suspect that the heat is going into deeper levels of the oceans, where satellites can't measure it like they can for the surface temps.
In the end, the real driver is the increase in carbon dioxide...as that goes up, reflection of infrared radiation back to the earth's surface goes up and the energy balance says the Earth must warm up.

As to your point about the Earth climate always changing...exactly right...the issue with climate change is not saving the Earth, it's saving humanity. The Earth could give a rat's behind about us humans and all the other species we're probably going to obliterate with us...bacteria, algea, cockroaches,ants, etc. will all survive and in a few 10's of millions of years a bunch of new species will grow back to fill all the niches of the planet. I wish the environmentalists would learn to appeal to the baser instincts of the deniers, by pointing out that simple fact. The Koch brothers aren't killing the Earth with their polluting companies, they're indirectly killing their great grandchildren...although the 0.01% like them can afford to move to the Alps, or Detroit to avoid the climate catastrophe for a while longer than the rest of us, but it will catch them eventually, and desperate, hungry 99.9%'ers with guns can get over mansion walls pretty fast!
This works both ways. If the reason for 30% interest or more on high risk loans is justified, when the risk is reduced in ways such as this the interest rates should be as well.
In a democracy the majority of the voters get the leaders they deserve.
Of course.  Money and misinformation...although I tend to call it, money and outright lies...are the only things the GOPTP have going.   Hopefully money and lying won't work this time!
They're gonna need a bigger boat.

Florida has a large population of seniors.  Rick Scott's health care company was fined the largest amount in U.S. history for Medicare fraud.  Knowing this the seniors voted Scott into office anyway for his first term.  Now the state, which will incur the largest amount of damage in the U.S. from climate change is about to vote Scott in for a second term, a man who will not admit that human behavior has an impact on climate change. Gullible doesn't even begin to describe it.
What dis you expect...You got all the news that fit the narrative. Why bother with interfering fcts.

Robert - They don't have "devices", they have codes -- which the article states often not work according to most borrowers.  The point really is that no company should be able to automatically shut down access to your car (which you have been paying for) because you're a day or 2 late -- and further, two of the cases in the article, in reality they had NEVER been late but their cars had been shut down anyway.

The article's opening emotional case and the same case presented in the video are contradictory?  Ms. Bolender shows she has a device to restart the car for emergency purposes but explains she does not like to depend on the grace of the lender to get her girl to the emergency room.  The written text suggests no such option and frankly reads as if she never made it to the emergency room.

There is no one like FDR coming along because for most people things simply aren't bad enough and they believe the FOX propaganda.  But even if they don't, gerrymandered districts guarantee the reelection of most congressional members including the craven, the sexual predators, the federally indicted ex-FBI.  The dysfunction of Congress to the point where they are on vacation for seven weeks rather than debate questions of war and peace says everything you need to know about the devolution of democracy into oligarchy.  Those of us past 50 won't live to see the nightmare world these sycophants to corporate America are producing in their denial of global warming, but I am ill when I think of my poor grandchildren.
Three letters, eh?

Martin,

I don't want to say anything bad about this puzzle but I don't have anything good to say about it either.
OH!!! You have evidence that Goodell is lying?  Perhaps you should provide that to the NFL or ESPN?   It's amazing how many things people "know" these days.

No we don't have the evidence that Goodell is lying, but all of that will come out when the independent commission headed by the ex FBI director from a law firm formerly tied to the Raven's owner does it's thorough investigation and ...... Oh wait!
Gotta love ESPN.  Suspsend a guy for a week who says 'women should not provoke men into hitting them.'  Suspend a guy for 3 weeks who tells the truth.  Amazing.

Social scientific studies claim to demonstrate that there is no relationship between money and policy. They are good studies. They are wrong. They can't get at the facts. This article is the facts. And the facts are that money buys policy.

Corruption, not democracy, is the name of the game in America. Anybody who thinks otherwise is not reading the paper very carefully.
Or a round planet earth. Or one that revolves around the sun.

"Only 3 percent of current Republican members of Congress have been willing to go on record as accepting the fact that people are causing global warming."

Heck, these days I'd be surprised if more than 3 percent of current Republican members of Congress even accept evolution.
Obama is now sounding and acting like Bush II.  Maybe Cheney is telling him what to do.

How sad to see a man who inspired our hopes for historic transformation turned minion of the military-industrial complex. Stockholm just awarded an "alternative Nobel prize" in human rights to Edward Snowden, our true heroes are forged by courage and principle Mr. Obama.
Her point is very well taken.
